title: 115_s1566
content: The "Care And Readiness Enhancement for Reservists Act of 2017" or the "CARE for Reservists Act of 2017" expands eligibility for readjustment counseling and outpatient services from the Department of Veterans Affairs to include members of the reserve components of the Armed Forces. The "CARE for Reservists Act of 2017" allows members of the reserve components of the Armed Forces to receive counseling and outpatient services without needing a referral. The "CARE for Reservists Act of 2017" allows individuals to receive counseling and outpatient services without needing a referral. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must evaluate workload to determine if more Vet Centers are needed to handle service expansion. The "CARE for Reservists Act of 2017" allows individuals to receive counseling and outpatient services without needing a referral. If workload treating members of the Armed Forces exceeds workload treating veterans at a Vet Center, discussions with the Secretary of Defense may lead to a reimbursable memorandum of understanding. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must submit a report to relevant committees within one year of the Act's enactment. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must provide a report to relevant committees on the evaluation and discussions with the Secretary of Defense. The Chief Officer of the Readjustment Counseling Service must have necessary resources for expansion. The amendments made by subsections (a) and (b) will take effect 90 days after the enactment of the Act. The term "Vet Center" is defined in section 1712A(h) of title 38, United States Code. Report on mental health and related services provided by the Department of Veterans Affairs to members of the Armed Forces who served in classified missions. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must submit a report to Congress within one year of this Act's enactment, assessing the increase in Armed Forces members using readjustment counseling or outpatient mental health care from the Department of Veterans Affairs. The report should also include data on reserve component members receiving telemental health care. The report to Congress must assess the increase in Armed Forces members using readjustment counseling or outpatient mental health care from the Department of Veterans Affairs, including data on reserve component members receiving telemental health care. It should also cover the annual cost increase, changes in staffing, training, organization, and resources needed for providing these services, as well as any challenges encountered in offering them to reserve component members.
